question.title: Facing Joe Biden instead of a generic Democrat, will Trump gain at least 3% among Manifold respondents?
question.body:
There are two Manifold polls posted, which both close on July 6.  One of the polls asks Manifold respondents to vote with Joe Biden on a hypothetical ballot, and another asks respondents to vote with a generic Democrat on the hypothetical ballot.

@/SteveSokolowski/1-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul@/SteveSokolowski/2-of-2-given-these-choices-who-woul 

Public opinion polls consistently show Joe Biden losing to Donald Trump outside the margin of error, but every other Democrat hypothetically surveyed polls ahead or within the margin of error.  Are Manifold respondents representative of the general public?

This market will resolve YES if the percentage of votes for Donald Trump in poll 1 exceeds that in poll 2 by 3% or more when both polls close.

The formula for determining the percentage of votes for Trump is (Trump / (Trump + (the Democrat in the question) + Someone else)).  The answer is YES if this formula for poll 1 - the formula for poll 2 >= 0.03.  Otherwise, it is NO.

The polls and this question will never resolve N/A, and will remain open until the close time no matter what.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question revolves around whether Donald Trump will gain at least a 3% advantage over Joe Biden compared to a generic Democrat among Manifold respondents. Historical polling data indicates that Joe Biden has faced challenges in head-to-head matchups against Trump, often trailing or being within the margin of error against him. In contrast, generic Democrats tend to perform better against Trump in hypothetical matchups. This suggests that voters may have a more favorable view of a generic Democrat compared to Biden, potentially leading to a smaller share of votes for Trump when Biden is the candidate. Given the nature of the polls and the trend observed in public opinion, it seems plausible that Trump could gain a significant percentage of support against Biden. However, the 3% threshold is a notable margin and could be challenging to achieve, especially considering the possibility that Biden's support may hold up better than expected among the Manifold respondents. Taking these factors into account, while there is a reasonable chance that Trump might exceed the 3% margin in favor of Biden, it is not guaranteed. Thus, I estimate a moderate probability that the question resolves YES.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question. (b) Resolves **Yes** if one of these individuals is the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump, Donald Trump Jr., Eric Trump, Ivanka Trump, Tiffany Trump, Melania Trump, Barron Trump.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To evaluate the probability of either event occurring, we need to analyze both components of the question. (a) Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average: As of the latest data available (July 5, 2024), Trump has a lead of 2.4 points over Biden. Given that polling can fluctuate and that we are a couple of weeks away from the date in question, it is plausible that Trump's lead could remain within this range, especially considering the historical context of polling averages. However, it is also possible that the lead could decrease or increase beyond this range as the election approaches, making this scenario somewhat uncertain but still plausible. (b) A member of the Trump family being the Republican nominee for the US Presidency in 2024: Donald Trump has been a strong contender for the Republican nomination, and there is also a possibility that one of his family members could run, particularly Donald Trump Jr. or Ivanka Trump. Given the political landscape and the influence of the Trump family within the Republican party, this scenario also seems quite likely. Both components of the question are independent but favorable towards a YES resolution. Considering the polling trends and the political dynamics at play, I would estimate a higher probability for the question resolving YES.

question.title: [Metaculus] Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democra...nomination for President?
question.body:
Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?

Resolves the same as the original on Metaculus.

(https://www.metaculus.com/questions/question_embed/25755/?theme=dark)Resolution criteria

This question will resolve as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a Yes resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as No.

Fine print and additional background information can be found on Metaculus.

Once the original resolves, its resolution will be applied to this market automatically. Trustworthy-ish users are encouraged to resolve this market before then if the outcome is known and unambiguous. Feel free to ping @jskf to request early resolution or to report issues.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Joe Biden has not made any definitive statements indicating he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President in 2024. Given that he is the incumbent president, there are substantial political pressures and incentives for him to seek re-election. Historically, incumbents often run for a second term unless there are compelling reasons not to, such as health issues or significant political challenges. Additionally, the Democratic Party is likely to support his candidacy, and any announcement of non-acceptance would require careful consideration of the political landscape, including potential successors and party unity. While it is possible that he could choose not to run, the lack of current indications and the typical behavior of incumbents leads me to believe that a public announcement of non-acceptance is unlikely before the specified date. Therefore, I would estimate the probability of this question resolving YES to be relatively low.

question.title: Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate?
question.body: Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g. Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, the Democratic Party has not finalized its primary schedule, but there is a strong likelihood that there will be debates among the candidates prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Historically, presidential primaries include debates to help voters assess the candidates and their policies. Given the competitive nature of the Democratic primaries, it is reasonable to expect that candidates like Kamala Harris, Gavin Newsom, Gretchen Whitmer, and potentially others will seek opportunities to debate each other to gain visibility and support. Additionally, the party typically organizes debates to engage voters and stimulate discussion around key issues. While the exact number and timing of these debates can vary, the presence of multiple candidates suggests that at least one debate will occur before the convention. Therefore, I would estimate a high probability that there will be another Democratic party presidential debate.

question.title: Will either Joe Biden announce he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024, or will there be another Democratic party presidential debate?
question.body:
(a) Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024, that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President? This resolves as Yes if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement that he will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. The statement must be unambiguous and conclusive.

(b) Will there be another Democratic party presidential debate? Resolves YES if there is a debate between potential Democratic nominees (e.g., Harris, Newsom, Whitmer, Biden, etc.) prior to the 2024 Democratic National Convention. Resolves NO otherwise.

This combined question resolves as YES if either (a) Joe Biden makes the announcement as described, or (b) there is another Democratic party presidential debate as described.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability of the combined question resolving as YES, we need to analyze the two components:

(a) Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic nomination before July 15, 2024: As of now, Joe Biden has indicated intentions to run for re-election, and there has been no significant indication from him or his campaign that he would step back from this position. Given the political landscape, it seems unlikely he would make such an announcement, especially considering the implications it would have on his party and potential challengers. Therefore, the likelihood of this part resolving as YES is quite low.

(b) The occurrence of another Democratic party presidential debate: Historically, debates are a common part of the nomination process, and given the competitive nature of the Democratic primaries, it is probable that there will be at least one more debate before the convention. Various candidates are likely to emerge, and debates serve as critical platforms for them to present their views and gain visibility. Therefore, the likelihood of this part resolving as YES is relatively high.

Since the combined question resolves as YES if either (a) or (b) resolves as YES, the overall probability leans towards YES primarily due to the expectation of a debate. However, the low probability of Biden's announcement weighs down the overall estimate slightly.

Taking these factors into account, I would estimate the probability of the combined question resolving as YES to be around 0.7.

question.title:
Will the  CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS)	
 be higher Year-over-Year on July 20, 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve based on reporting by the St. Louis Fed here: https://fred.stlouisfed.org/series/VXVCLS. The reported number for July 20, 2024 must be greater than the reported number on July 20, 2023.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The CBOE S&P 500 3-Month Volatility Index (VXVCLS) measures the market's expectation of future volatility based on S&P 500 index options. To determine whether the VXVCLS will be higher year-over-year on July 20, 2024, we must consider several factors that influence market volatility:

1. **Market Conditions**: Volatility often increases during periods of economic uncertainty, geopolitical tensions, or significant market events. If the global or national economic landscape is unstable, it's likely that the VXVCLS will rise.

2. **Historical Trends**: Analyzing historical data can provide insight into typical volatility patterns. If the previous year (2023) experienced a relatively stable market, it could lead to lower volatility. Conversely, if 2024 is expected to have significant events (like elections, economic reports, etc.), volatility may increase.

3. **Current Economic Indicators**: As of 2023, if there are indicators such as rising inflation, interest rate changes, or other economic shifts, they could contribute to increased market volatility in 2024.

4. **Market Sentiment**: Investor sentiment can greatly impact volatility. If investors expect significant changes or are reacting to news, this could lead to fluctuations in the VXVCLS.

Given the unpredictability of these factors and the tendency for volatility to fluctuate based on market conditions, I would estimate a moderate probability that the VXVCLS will be higher year-over-year. The market has been known to experience cycles of volatility, and while there are factors that could lead to an increase, there are also stabilizing forces that could keep volatility lower.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

Still, given the current landscape, I estimate a high probability that he will secure the nomination.

question.title: Will Google DeepMind publish a report with results from external red-teaming of their models for safety by June 30, 2024?
question.body: For Google DeepMind, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Google DeepMind has been increasingly focused on AI safety and transparency, particularly as public concern over AI technologies grows. The trend in the AI industry is moving towards more rigorous safety evaluations and accountability, often involving external audits and red-teaming exercises. Given that DeepMind has a history of engaging with the research community and has previously published findings related to AI safety, it is plausible that they would publish a report resulting from external red-teaming. Additionally, the timeline extends until June 30, 2024, which provides ample time for such evaluations to take place and for a report to be prepared and released. However, the decision to publish such a report may also depend on internal policies, the nature of the findings, and strategic considerations. Overall, while there are uncertainties, the likelihood of Google DeepMind publishing a report by the specified date seems reasonably high.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

metadata.chain_of_thought: The availability of ChatGPT in the European Union by June 30, 2024, hinges on several factors including regulatory compliance, market strategy, and technological developments. OpenAI has been actively expanding its services and addressing regulatory concerns in various regions, including the EU. Given the trend of increasing availability of AI services and the potential for OpenAI to adapt to regulatory frameworks, it is reasonable to expect that by mid-2024, ChatGPT will be generally available in the EU. The requirement that more than 50% of the population can access it, even if there are some restrictions in specific countries or for certain age groups, is also likely to be met, as OpenAI would likely aim for broad accessibility. Therefore, while there are uncertainties, the likelihood of ChatGPT being generally available in the EU by the specified date appears strong.

question.body:
(a) For Google DeepMind, this resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

If unavailable in certain EU countries, or unavailable to certain groups (e.g., minors), this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it. "ChatGPT" refers to the general web interface for interacting with GPT models, and resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the probability of either scenario (a) or (b) occurring by June 30, 2024, we need to analyze the likelihood of each event separately.

(a) Google DeepMind publishing a report from external red-teaming is plausible given the increasing emphasis on AI safety and transparency. In recent years, there has been a growing trend among tech companies to engage with external parties for auditing and safety evaluations, especially in light of regulatory pressures and public scrutiny. Given the timeline, it is reasonable to expect that DeepMind could produce such a report, particularly if they are actively working on AI safety initiatives.

(b) OpenAI's ChatGPT being generally available in the European Union by June 30, 2024, seems very likely as well. OpenAI has been expanding its services globally, and there is significant demand for AI tools in the EU. Regulatory hurdles may exist, but companies often adapt to comply with local regulations. Given the precedent of other tech companies successfully launching their services in the EU, it is reasonable to expect that OpenAI will make ChatGPT available to the majority of the EU population by the specified date.

Considering both scenarios are likely to occur, I would assess the overall probability of at least one of them happening by June 30, 2024, as quite high.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Trump's lead over Biden being greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 on July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors that could influence polling trends leading up to that date. 1. Current Polling Trends: As of now, Trump's lead is fluctuating, and while he has shown some capacity to maintain a lead, the magnitude of that lead can change significantly due to various factors, including economic conditions, voter sentiment, and major events in the political landscape. 2. Historical Context: Historically, polling averages can show significant swings in the months leading up to an election, especially as debates occur, campaigns intensify, and voter engagement increases. The time frame from now until July 2024 is considerable, and it is likely that both candidates will have their ups and downs in the polls. 3. Biden's Approval Ratings: Biden's approval ratings and the state of the economy will heavily influence his support. If economic conditions worsen or if key issues arise that sway public opinion, Biden could see a drop in support, potentially allowing Trump to increase his lead. 4. Demographics and Key States: The demographics of voters and the state of key battleground states will also play a significant role. If Trump manages to solidify his support among key demographics or if Biden loses ground in crucial states, this could contribute to a larger lead. 5. Statistical Analysis: Based on historical polling data and considering the volatility of public opinion, a lead of around 3 to 4 points is plausible but not guaranteed. Given that polling averages can be influenced by many variables, the probability of Trump's lead ending up specifically in that range is uncertain. Taking all these factors into account, I would estimate that while there is a reasonable chance for Trump to have a lead in that range, the exact nature of polling dynamics makes it somewhat uncertain.

Historically, incumbents or leading candidates tend to have varying levels of support based on current events, economic conditions, and public sentiment. The specific condition of Trump's lead being greater than 3 and less than or equal to 4 is quite narrow, but it is plausible, especially if the political environment remains favorable for Trump. Considering these factors, the probability of either scenario occurring seems reasonably high. Cruz has a non-negligible chance of being the nominee, and Trump's polling lead, while uncertain, could easily fall within the specified range depending on how the campaigns unfold.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Russia having control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024, we need to consider the ongoing military dynamics in Ukraine, particularly in the Donetsk region where Chasiv Yar is located. As of now, the conflict has been characterized by fluctuating frontlines and both sides have experienced gains and losses. Russia has made significant territorial advances in the past, but the situation is fluid. The Ukrainian military has shown resilience and has conducted counteroffensives that have regained territory. The ISW's assessments are based on current intelligence and battlefield reports, which can change rapidly. Given the current state of the conflict and the potential for Ukrainian counteractions, it is difficult to predict with certainty that Russia will maintain control over Chasiv Yar by June 2024. However, if we consider the possibility that Russia may solidify its control through continued military efforts or lack of effective Ukrainian counteroffensives, there is a reasonable chance that it could be classified under one of the ISW's categories indicating Russian control. Taking into account the complexities of the situation, I would estimate a moderate probability that Russia will control Chasiv Yar by the resolution date.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question revolves around the interpretation and application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment, which addresses the disqualification from holding office for individuals who have engaged in insurrection or rebellion against the United States. As of now, there is significant debate and legal uncertainty regarding whether this provision could be applied to Donald Trump, particularly in the context of his actions surrounding the January 6 Capitol riots.

Several factors complicate the likelihood of Trump being removed or blocked from the ballot under this provision:

1. **Legal Interpretations**: Courts have yet to definitively rule on the application of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to Trump. While some legal scholars argue that his actions could qualify, others contend that the historical context and legal precedents may not support such a disqualification.

2. **Political Landscape**: The political environment in various states may influence decisions regarding ballot access. Republican-led states may be less inclined to remove Trump from the ballot, whereas Democratic-led states might pursue such actions more vigorously. However, state-level decisions may still be subject to legal challenges.

3. **Timing**: The resolution date is set for July 15, 2024, which is just a few months before the presidential election. This timing may discourage states from taking drastic actions that could lead to significant political backlash or legal disputes.

4. **Public Sentiment and Media Influence**: The media and public opinion could play a role in shaping the actions of state officials. However, unless there is a clear and overwhelming legal basis for removal, it is likely that many states will avoid taking such a contentious step.

Given these factors, while it is possible that a state could attempt to block Trump under Section 3, the lack of a clear legal precedent, the political implications, and the timing suggest that it is unlikely that he will be officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot in any state by the specified date.

question.title: Will the Orlando Magic win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Orlando Magic are crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams as they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The Orlando Magic's chances of winning the 2024 NBA Finals depend on several factors, including their current roster strength, performance in the regular season, playoff positioning, and competition from other teams. As of October 2023, the Magic have been a developing team with a mix of young talent and potential, but they have not consistently been seen as a top contender in the Eastern Conference. Historical performance, current standings, and the strength of other teams like the Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, and Miami Heat also play a significant role in their likelihood of winning the championship. Given these considerations, while it's possible for the Magic to make a deep playoff run, the probability of them winning the Finals appears low compared to more established teams.

question.title: Will the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the New York Knicks are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** for all other teams if they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The New York Knicks have a storied history in the NBA, but their recent performance and current roster dynamics will heavily influence their chances of winning the 2024 NBA Finals. As of now, the team has shown promise with a mix of young talent and experienced players, which can be a strong foundation for a championship run. However, the competition in the Eastern Conference is fierce, with teams like the Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, and Philadelphia 76ers also vying for the title. Factors such as injuries, team chemistry, and performance during the regular season and playoffs will play critical roles in determining their success. Given the unpredictability of playoff basketball and the strength of their competition, I estimate that the Knicks have a moderate chance of winning the finals but face significant hurdles. Therefore, I would assign a probability of around 25% to the Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals.

question.title: Will either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks are crowned the champions of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). It resolves as **No** if neither team wins the championship and they are both eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors, including the current performance of both teams, their rosters, coaching staff, and overall competitiveness in the league. As of the latest available data in October 2023, the Orlando Magic and New York Knicks have shown varying degrees of potential in recent seasons. The Knicks have made strides in recent years, including playoff appearances and a relatively strong roster. The Magic, while historically less successful, have been rebuilding and have young talent that could potentially make them competitive. However, both teams face strong competition in the Eastern Conference, with teams like the Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, and Miami Heat being formidable contenders. The probability of either team winning the Finals also depends on their health, performance consistency, and ability to navigate the playoffs successfully. Given the unpredictability of playoff outcomes and the strength of other teams, while it is possible for either team to win, it is not highly probable. Taking into account all these factors, I estimate that the likelihood of either the Orlando Magic or the New York Knicks winning the 2024 NBA Finals is moderate but not overwhelmingly high.

question.body:
(a) Will "House of the Dragon" S2E7 (title TBA) be rated >8.5 on IMDB, 2 days after release? This resolves based on the score displayed two days after release (July 30th), at noon PT. The market closes 90 minutes after the episode premieres. The precision listed by IMDB is typically a single decimal, and this is a strict inequality. Current IMDB ratings for HotD are provided for context.

(b) Will the linked market get at least 377 traders by end of July 15? Resolves YES if the market embedded in the link has 377 traders before market close (July 15, 11:59 PM Pacific Time). Resolves NO otherwise. The link to the market is: https://manifold.markets/embed/Mira_/how-many-traders-will-this-market-g

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To address the question, we need to analyze both parts (a) and (b) separately.

(a) The rating of "House of the Dragon" S2E7 on IMDB after its release: "House of the Dragon" has received generally favorable reviews, and the first season had several episodes rated above 8.5. Given that the show has established a dedicated fan base and strong critical reception, it is reasonable to expect that the second season will continue to perform well. However, the rating is influenced by audience reactions, which can vary widely in the first few days after release. While I believe there is a good chance the episode could achieve a rating above 8.5, I would not classify it as highly certain due to the variability in audience reception. Therefore, I estimate the probability of this part resolving YES to be around 0.65.

(b) The likelihood of the linked market reaching at least 377 traders: The success of a market in attracting traders often depends on the interest in the event being discussed. Given that "House of the Dragon" is a popular show, there is a significant chance that a market related to its episodes would attract a good number of participants. However, whether it reaches 377 traders by the specified date also depends on the marketing of the market and the level of engagement from the community. Given the popularity of the show, I would estimate a moderate to high probability that it will reach this threshold, around 0.70.

To determine the overall probability of either event occurring, we can apply the principle of inclusion-exclusion. The probability that at least one of the events occurs can be calculated as:
P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)

Assuming that the events are somewhat independent, we can approximate P(A and B) as P(A) * P(B). Therefore:
P(A or B) = 0.65 + 0.70 - (0.65 * 0.70) = 0.65 + 0.70 - 0.455 = 0.895.

Thus, the overall probability that at least one of the events (either the episode rating >8.5 or the market reaching 377 traders) occurs is approximately 0.895.

question.title: Before July 1, 2024, will the International Criminal Court issue arrest warrants for any of the listed Israeli leaders?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if before July 1, 2024, the International Criminal Court (ICC) issues a [warrant of arrest](https://www.icc-cpi.int/about/how-the-court-works) for any of the below listed Israeli cabinet members. It will resolve as **No** otherwise.

* Benjamin Netanyahu (Prime Minister)
* Yoav Gallant (Defense Minister)
* Herzi Halevi (IDF Chief of Staff)

metadata.chain_of_thought: The International Criminal Court (ICC) has been involved in various investigations regarding potential war crimes and crimes against humanity, particularly concerning the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The likelihood of the ICC issuing arrest warrants can depend on several factors, including ongoing investigations, political considerations, and international pressure. As of now, there have been discussions and preliminary investigations into actions taken by Israeli leaders, but the process of issuing arrest warrants is complex and often influenced by geopolitical dynamics. Given the timeline—before July 1, 2024—there is a possibility that the ICC may act, especially if there are significant developments or escalations in the conflict. However, historically, the ICC moves cautiously, and the issuance of arrest warrants for high-profile leaders is a significant step that is not taken lightly. The current political climate in Israel and international relations may also impact this decision. Considering all these factors, while there is a chance that arrest warrants could be issued, it is still relatively uncertain and would require a strong basis in evidence and political will. Therefore, I estimate a moderate probability that the ICC will issue arrest warrants for the listed Israeli leaders before the specified date.

question.title: Will a terrorist act occur in metropolitan France during the 2024 Summer Olympics?
question.body:
The question will resolve as Yes if a terrorist attack in [Metropolitan France](https://en.m.wikipedia.org/wiki/Metropolitan_France) injures and/or kills at least one person, other than the terrorist(s), between, and inclusive of, the day of the Opening Ceremony (26 July 2024) and the day of the Closing Ceremony (11 August 2024). The question will resolve as No if the above does not happen.

An event will be considered a 'terrorist attack' if it is described as such by any agency of the State of France, or by the French President, Prime Minister, or a member of the Council of Ministers.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris is a high-profile international event that typically attracts significant attention and security concerns. Historically, major events have been targets for terrorist activities due to their visibility and the potential for mass casualties. France has experienced several terrorist attacks in recent years, which heightens the likelihood of such incidents occurring during a major event like the Olympics. The French government is likely to implement extensive security measures to mitigate these risks, but the presence of heightened security does not eliminate the possibility of a terrorist act. Additionally, the timeframe of the Olympics spans multiple weeks, providing ample opportunity for such an event to occur. Given these factors, while the government will be on high alert and proactive in preventing attacks, the inherent risks associated with large gatherings and the historical context suggest a non-negligible probability of a terrorist act occurring.

For scenario (a), the ICC's actions are often influenced by political contexts, international relations, and ongoing investigations. While tensions exist regarding Israeli leaders and their actions, the issuance of arrest warrants is a complex legal process that requires substantial evidence and international cooperation. Historically, the ICC has been cautious in its approach, especially regarding high-profile political figures, making this scenario relatively uncertain.

For scenario (b), the potential for a terrorist attack during a high-profile event like the 2024 Summer Olympics in Paris is a significant concern for security agencies. Given the global context of terrorism and past incidents during major international events, the risk of an attack cannot be dismissed. Considering both scenarios, the likelihood of at least one of them occurring before the resolution date of August 11, 2024, is more probable than not. While the ICC's actions are uncertain, the risk of a terrorist act during such a significant event is considerable.

metadata.chain_of_thought:

Given these considerations, I would estimate a moderate probability that Malta qualifies for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024.

question.title: Will Will Hurd be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Will Hurd is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently below; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Will Hurd is a relatively lesser-known candidate in the Republican primary for the 2024 US Presidential Election. As of my last knowledge update in October 2023, he has not gained significant traction compared to more prominent figures in the Republican Party, such as Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. The Republican National Convention is likely to favor candidates with stronger polling numbers and broader support within the party. Given the competitive nature of the primary and the established popularity of other candidates, it seems quite unlikely that Hurd would secure the nomination. Therefore, the probability of him being the nominee is low.

question.title: Will Donald Trump testify at the hush money trial?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if [credible sources](https://www.metaculus.com/help/faq/#definitions) report Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the [trial](https://iapps.courts.state.ny.us/webcrim_attorney/Detail?which=case&docketNumber=q23XFOwZRDQ1d4LrNRdw2clqCMt/CzUoG/kRII/7Nmg=&countyId=K4i18rFVPQh5HTQ/kUoO3Q==&docketId=3Y4iKU5oHM75AtDme2cPhw==&docketDseq=T/O1YN_PLUS_BG65HkOeqEnpAkw==&defendantName=TRUMP,+DONALD&court=New+York+Supreme+Criminal+Court&courtType=U&recordType=U&recordNum=) concerning the so-called "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The question of whether Donald Trump will testify at the hush money trial involves several factors, including the legal strategy of his defense team, the political implications of his testimony, and the evolving nature of the case itself. Historically, high-profile defendants like Trump might choose to testify to present their side of the story, especially in cases that have garnered significant media attention. However, they may also decide against it to avoid potential pitfalls in cross-examination. As of now, there have been no definitive announcements regarding Trump's intention to testify, but given the high stakes of the trial and the public interest, it is plausible that he may choose to do so. The trial is set to occur before the resolution date, which also increases the likelihood that testimony could be given. Additionally, the legal landscape surrounding the case may change, influencing Trump's decision. Overall, while there are arguments for both sides, the probability leans towards the possibility of Trump testifying, either to assert his position or due to legal obligations. Therefore, I assess the probability that he will testify at the trial as moderately high.

This is determined solely by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention, not who receives the nomination on the day of the 2024 US election. (b) Credible sources report that Donald Trump has testified, whether in person or remotely, at the trial concerning the "hush money" payments to Stormy Daniels.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the likelihood of the question resolving as YES, we need to consider both scenarios outlined in the question: (a) Will Hurd being selected as the Republican nominee and (b) Donald Trump testifying at the hush money trial.

1. **Will Hurd's Nomination**: As of now, Will Hurd is a relatively lesser-known candidate compared to frontrunners like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. The Republican primary has been heavily dominated by Trump, who has a strong base and significant name recognition. Historically, the nomination tends to favor candidates with more established support, making Hurd's chances of winning the nomination quite slim. Therefore, I estimate the probability of Hurd being the nominee as low.

2. **Donald Trump's Testimony**: While there has been significant legal scrutiny surrounding Trump, including the hush money payments to Stormy Daniels, the outcome of his trial and whether he will testify is uncertain. However, given the high-profile nature of the case and Trump's tendency to engage with media and legal processes, it is plausible that credible sources could report him testifying. The legal landscape is complex, but the possibility of Trump testifying is more likely than Hurd being nominated.

Considering both scenarios, the overall probability of at least one occurring leans more towards the likelihood of Trump testifying rather than Hurd being nominated. Therefore, while both scenarios have low individual probabilities, the combined likelihood of at least one happening results in a moderate estimate.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probability that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors including current polling trends, historical data, and potential events that could influence voter sentiment leading up to the election.

As of now, polling data indicates that Trump has been leading Biden by varying margins. Recent trends show that Trump's lead has fluctuated, and while he has had periods of a lead greater than 2 points, there is also potential for Biden to gain ground as the election approaches. However, considering the current political climate, Trump's lead is likely to remain within a narrow margin, especially with the election being highly competitive.

Given the historical context of polling averages and the volatility of political campaigns, it seems reasonable to predict that there is a moderate chance that Trump's lead will fall within the specified range of greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 points. The dynamics of the election, including debates, economic conditions, and public sentiment, will play a crucial role in shaping these numbers.

Overall, I estimate a probability of around 0.65 that Trump's lead over Biden will be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on the specified date.

question.title: Will Joe Biden have an in-person interview/conversation on camera for 45+ minutes, before the end of July 2024?
question.body:
The most recent qualifying interview was Biden's appearance on The Howard Stern Show in April, when Biden answered questions for ~70 minutes. 

If Biden appears in another such in-person interview for at least 45 minutes, this market resolves YES. If no qualifying interview is released before market close at the end of July, this market resolves NO. 

This market does not include press conferences, speeches, rallies, fundraisers, town halls, etc. It can include appearances on a podcast or late night show, or an interview edited into a show like 60 minutes. However, there must be at least 45 minutes of new footage of Biden being interviewed in-person for such appearances to count. A 50 minute video might only feature 20 minutes of video of Biden being interviewed, and so would not count.

For context, Biden's interview with Stephanopoulos in July, his appearance on Jimmy Fallon in February, and his past appearances on 60 minutes have each had less than 30 minutes of video footage of Biden being interviewed.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The Greens–EFA (European Free Alliance) group has been gaining popularity in recent years, especially as issues related to climate change and environmental policy have become more prominent in European politics. However, they are currently not the largest group in the European Parliament, trailing behind the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). The 2024 European Parliamentary Elections will likely see a continuation of this trend, with traditional parties like the EPP maintaining significant support. While the Greens may increase their number of seats, it is unlikely they will surpass the larger groups to hold the most seats. Additionally, the political landscape can be unpredictable, and factors such as voter turnout, emerging political movements, and coalition dynamics will play crucial roles. Given these considerations, I estimate that the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 elections is relatively low.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To estimate the probability that FiveThirtyEight will project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024, we need to consider several factors. First, the current political landscape, including Biden's approval ratings, key policy issues, and Trump's ongoing legal challenges, could impact public perception and polling data leading up to that date. Historically, incumbents tend to have an advantage, especially if the economy is stable or improving. Additionally, the Democratic Party's base is generally more unified than the Republican Party's, which could bolster Biden's chances.

Moreover, as the election date approaches, polling data is likely to become more predictive of actual outcomes, and FiveThirtyEight's model incorporates a variety of factors, including polling averages and historical data. If Biden maintains a competitive edge or if significant events favor him, it is plausible that he could be projected as the favorite.

Given these considerations, while there is still a significant amount of uncertainty in political forecasting, the factors currently suggest a reasonable likelihood that Biden will be favored by FiveThirtyEight on the specified date. However, this is contingent on the evolving political context and any major developments that could shift voter sentiment.

question.title: Will either Tim Scott be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election or will 538 project Biden as the favorite on July 19, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Tim Scott is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election; (b) Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024.

For part (a), it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

For part (b), the resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market. The resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (e.g., "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the question resolving as YES, we need to analyze the two conditions separately: (a) Tim Scott being selected as the Republican nominee, and (b) Joe Biden being projected as the favorite by FiveThirtyEight. For part (a), Tim Scott's chances of becoming the Republican nominee depend on several factors, including his performance in the primaries, the overall political landscape, and the presence of other candidates. As of now, Tim Scott has not been a frontrunner in polls compared to other candidates like Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis. However, if he performs well in early primaries or if the Republican base shifts towards his platform, his chances could improve. Given the current dynamics, I would estimate his chances of being the nominee relatively low, perhaps around 20%. For part (b), FiveThirtyEight's projections are based on polling data, which can fluctuate significantly as the election approaches. As of now, Joe Biden has been consistently polling well against Donald Trump, but this can change based on various factors such as economic conditions, major events, and voter sentiment. If Biden maintains a solid approval rating and the economy stays stable, it is plausible that he could be projected as the favorite. Given the current political climate, I would estimate Biden's chances of being the favorite at around 60%. Combining these two probabilities, we can use the formula for the probability of at least one event occurring: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Assuming independence for simplicity (though they may not be entirely independent), we have: P(Scott as nominee) = 0.20 P(Biden as favorite) = 0.60 P(Scott as nominee and Biden as favorite) = P(Scott as nominee) * P(Biden as favorite) = 0.20 * 0.60 = 0.12 Thus, P(A or B) = 0.20 + 0.60 - 0.12 = 0.68. Therefore, the overall probability that either Tim Scott will be the Republican nominee or Joe Biden will be projected as the favorite by July 19, 2024, is approximately 0.68.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as **No** if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in these eight team sports at the 2024 Paris Olympics: 

- association football 
- 3×3 basketball
- 5×5 basketball
- field hockey
- handball 
- rugby sevens
- volleyball
- water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

The question can resolve as soon as it becomes clear one of these conditions will happen (e.g. neither team playing the final of the last event has won any of the others).

Moreover, the nature of competition in these sports can lead to unexpected outcomes, but the likelihood of eight different nations winning gold across these sports is low, especially considering the strength of a few dominant nations. Therefore, it is reasonable to expect that at least one nation will win multiple gold medals.

question.title: Will Greens–EFA hold the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if the Greens–EFA political group holds the most seats after the 2024 European Parliament elections and as **No** for all other outcomes. If two groups are tied for seats, both sub-questions will resolve as **Yes**.

This question resolves on the basis of [official statements by the European Parliament](https://www.europarl.europa.eu/portal/en) or credible media reports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
The Greens–EFA (Group of the Greens/European Free Alliance) has been gaining popularity in recent years, particularly in the context of increasing public concern about climate change and environmental issues. However, they currently do not hold the most seats in the European Parliament; that position is typically dominated by larger groups such as the European People's Party (EPP) and the Progressive Alliance of Socialists and Democrats (S&D). 

For the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, several factors will influence the outcome, including voter turnout, the political climate, and the effectiveness of the Greens–EFA's campaigning. While they may gain some seats due to their rising popularity, it is unlikely that they will surpass the larger groups in terms of total seats. Additionally, the electoral system used in the European Parliament elections tends to favor larger parties, making it challenging for smaller groups like the Greens–EFA to secure the most seats.

Given these considerations, I estimate that the probability of the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 elections is relatively low.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To assess the probabilities for the two components of the question, we need to analyze both scenarios separately.

(a) Regarding Trump's lead over Biden in the 538 national polling average on July 15, 2024: As of now, polling data suggests a competitive race between Trump and Biden. Given the historical trends, it is possible for Trump's lead to fluctuate within a narrow range. However, considering the current political landscape, economic conditions, and voter sentiment, a lead between 2 and 3 points is plausible but not guaranteed. Polling averages can shift significantly in the months leading to the election, especially with various events that can influence public opinion. I would estimate a moderate probability of around 40% that Trump's lead will be between 2 and 3 points.

(b) For the Greens–EFA holding the most seats after the 2024 European Parliamentary Elections, the political dynamics in Europe are complex. The Greens have been gaining popularity in various EU member states, and their performance can vary significantly depending on national contexts. However, historically, the Greens have not been the largest party in the European Parliament, and while they may increase their seat count, it is less likely that they will surpass the larger traditional parties (like the EPP or S&D) to hold the most seats. Therefore, I would estimate a lower probability of about 25% for this scenario.

Now, since the question resolves as YES if either (a) or (b) occurs, we can combine the probabilities. The likelihood that at least one of the two events occurs can be calculated using the formula for the probability of at least one event occurring:

P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A) * P(B)

Substituting the probabilities:
P(A) = 0.40
P(B) = 0.25
P(A and B) = 0.40 * 0.25 = 0.10

Thus, P(A or B) = 0.40 + 0.25 - 0.10 = 0.55.

Therefore, the overall probability estimate that either of the two scenarios resolves YES is 0.55.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context indicates that there is a significant discontent among House Democrats regarding the early nomination of President Biden. The drafted letter by Rep. Jared Huffman suggests that there is a concerted effort among Democrats to express their opposition to the DNC's plan. Given that the letter is already in circulation and involves multiple lawmakers, it is plausible that at least 20 Democrats will sign it, especially considering the current political climate where party unity is being challenged by differing views on Biden's candidacy. The existence of dissent within the party, as highlighted by Huffman’s comments, suggests that there is enough motivation for lawmakers to publicly oppose the plan. Given these factors, it seems likely that the threshold of 20 signatures will be met, either through a single letter or multiple letters.

question.title: Will Larry Elder be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Larry Elder is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: Larry Elder, a conservative talk radio host and former California gubernatorial candidate, has announced his candidacy for the Republican nomination in the 2024 presidential election. However, the Republican primary field is expected to be competitive, with several prominent candidates such as former President Donald Trump, Florida Governor Ron DeSantis, and others potentially running. Given the current political landscape, Elder's name recognition and support may not be sufficient to secure the nomination against more established candidates. Additionally, the dynamics of the Republican primaries can change significantly as the election approaches, with factors such as endorsements, fundraising, and debate performances playing crucial roles. Based on this analysis, while there is a possibility that Elder could gain traction, it seems unlikely that he will be the chosen nominee.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: Reasoning: The invocation of the 25th Amendment, particularly Section 4, requires a significant consensus among the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet or another designated body. Historically, this has been a rare occurrence, as it involves a serious assessment of the President's ability to perform their duties. Currently, President Biden has not shown signs of incapacity that would warrant such a declaration, and there is no strong political momentum or indication that such an action will be taken by the Vice President and Cabinet. The context provided mentions a GOP lawmaker's request, but political requests do not equate to action, especially when the decision requires a majority agreement from the Cabinet, which is unlikely given the current political landscape and the loyalty of many Cabinet members to Biden. Therefore, the probability of Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 is quite low.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: As of now, Joe Biden has not made any definitive public statements indicating that he will not seek re-election in 2024. Historically, incumbent presidents have typically sought re-election unless there are significant political or personal reasons that would lead them to step aside. Biden's approval ratings and the political landscape within the Democratic Party also suggest that he is likely to run for a second term. Additionally, the timeline is important; with the announcement window closing just before the Democratic National Convention, it is unlikely that he would choose to make such an announcement so close to this critical period without a compelling reason. Therefore, the probability of him announcing that he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024, is low.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024 or (b) Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
(a) Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time). The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question. Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count. Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office. 

(b) This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle. To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle. If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
Reasoning: The question revolves around two distinct scenarios regarding President Biden. 

(a) The likelihood of Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 is relatively low. This requires a formal declaration by the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet, which is a significant political hurdle. Given the current political landscape and the fact that Biden has been actively fulfilling his presidential duties, this scenario appears unlikely to occur before August 2024.

(b) The possibility of Biden announcing that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination before July 15, 2024, is somewhat more plausible. Political dynamics can shift, and there could be various reasons for him to make such a statement, including health concerns or strategic political considerations. However, as of now, Biden has not indicated any intention to withdraw, and it is common for sitting presidents to seek re-election. 

Overall, while both scenarios have their challenges, the second scenario about Biden announcing he will not seek re-election seems more likely than the first. Therefore, considering both aspects, I would estimate the probability of either occurring as moderate.

question.title: Will the same nation win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics?
question.body:
This question resolves as No if women's teams representing eight different National Olympic Committees (NOC) win gold in the eight team sports - association football, 3×3 basketball, 5×5 basketball, field hockey, handball, rugby sevens, voleyball and water polo.

Otherwise, the same NOC must have won at least two of these events, so the question resolves as **Yes**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To determine the probability of the same nation winning more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics, we need to consider the competitive nature of the sports listed and the historical performance of nations in these events. There are eight team sports mentioned, and historically, certain nations have excelled in multiple team sports. For example, countries like the United States, Australia, and the Netherlands have strong women's teams in sports like basketball, soccer, and field hockey. Given that there are eight events and the possibility of multiple strong teams from the same nation, it seems plausible that at least one nation could win gold in more than one of these events. Moreover, the competitive landscape is such that while there are a variety of strong teams, the concentration of talent in certain countries makes it likely that they could dominate in multiple sports. The probability of eight different nations winning gold in all events appears low, considering the historical context and the strength of certain NOCs. Taking into account these factors, I estimate that the probability that the same nation will win more than one women's team sport at the 2024 Olympics is relatively high.

question.body:

The question will resolve as NO if neither (a) nor (b) occurs. Specifically, (a) will resolve as NO if the Democratic delegates select a male presidential nominee for the 2024 election, and (b) will resolve as NO if women's teams representing eight different NOCs win gold in the eight team sports.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To evaluate the probability of the question resolving YES, we need to consider both components of the question separately.

1. **Democratic Presidential Nominee**: The Democratic Party has a history of female candidates, and as of now, several prominent women are either running or being discussed as potential nominees for the 2024 election. For instance, countries like the USA and Australia have strong teams in multiple sports. If one of these nations performs well, it is quite feasible that they could win gold in more than one event. The competition is tough, and there are eight different sports, but the likelihood of one nation winning in multiple events is reasonable, given historical performance trends.

Considering both factors, there is a good chance that at least one of the two scenarios will occur. question.body:

metadata.chain_of_thought: To evaluate the likelihood of either event occurring, we need to consider the current political landscape and recent trends. For (a), Kamala Harris's odds of winning as per Nate Silver's model depend on various factors including polling data, public sentiment, and political developments. As of now, Harris's chances are influenced by her visibility in the political arena and any recent endorsements or events that could sway public opinion. If there is a significant political event or shift in public sentiment within the week leading up to August 9th, her odds could increase. However, if the political environment remains stable or if other candidates gain traction, her odds may not improve significantly. Given the current climate, I would estimate a moderate probability that her odds will increase, perhaps around 40% based on the uncertainty and volatility of political predictions. For (b), Joe Biden's potential announcement about not seeking the nomination is highly speculative. Biden has not indicated any intention to step aside, and given the nature of political announcements, it's unlikely that he would make such a definitive statement so far in advance of the election. Therefore, the probability of him making a clear announcement that he will not accept the nomination is low, likely around 20%. Combining these two probabilities, we consider the likelihood of at least one of the events occurring. Since both events are independent, we can use the formula for the probability of at least one event occurring: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Assuming P(A and B) is negligible (since they are unlikely to influence each other), we can estimate: P(at least one event) = P(A) + P(B) = 0.4 + 0.2 = 0.6. Thus, there is a reasonably good chance that either Kamala's odds will increase or Biden will announce he will not seek the nomination.

question.title: Will at least 20 House/Senate Democrats sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early?
question.body:
Context from Politico:

Dozens of House Democrats are organizing a plan to speak out against their own party’s effort to seal President Joe Biden’s nomination sooner than originally planned, which they argue stifles the intense ongoing debate about his candidacy, according to a lawmaker involved in the effort.

A drafted letter, circulated by Rep. Jared Huffman (D-Calif.) and obtained by POLITICO, offers the first public signal from Democrats since the weekend’s attempted assassination on former President Donald Trump that scores of their own members remain deeply unsettled about the future of Biden’s candidacy.

“It’s a really bad move by the DNC. Somebody thinks it’s a clever way to lock down debate and I guess by dint of sheer force, achieve unity, but it doesn’t work that way,” Huffman said in an interview. He declined to confirm the existence of a letter.

This market resolves YES if a public letter opposing the early nomination plan is signed by at least 20 House Members or Senators who caucus with the Democratic Party before market close at the end of Sunday, July 21st. 

Multiple such letters with a combined total of 20 lawmaker's signatures would also be sufficient to resolve this market to YES. 

If these criteria are not met by market close, this market resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: The context provided indicates that there is significant dissent among House Democrats regarding the plan to virtually nominate President Biden. The drafted letter, which is already in circulation, suggests that there is an organized effort to oppose this move. Given that this effort is spearheaded by a lawmaker involved in the opposition, it implies a level of seriousness and potential support from other members. Additionally, the fact that it has garnered attention and is being discussed publicly indicates that there is likely to be at least some traction among the caucus members. Considering the number of Democrats in the House and the fact that the letter is already being circulated, it seems reasonable to expect that at least 20 members will sign it, especially given that multiple letters could also suffice. While there may be some internal divisions and varying opinions, the urgency of the situation and the potential implications for the party's unity and electoral strategy could mobilize enough members to sign the letter. Therefore, I would estimate a relatively high probability that at least 20 House/Senate Democrats will sign a public letter opposing the plan to virtually nominate Biden early.
